citation.article-title: Characterization of Porphyrobacter sanguineus sp. nov., an aerobic bacteriochlorophyll-containing bacterium capable of degrading biphenyl and dibenzofuran

p.s: Description of Porphyrobacter sanguineus sp. nov.
Porphyrobacter sanguineus (san.gui'ne.us, L. adj. sanguineus blood-colored)
Cells are rod-shaped and pleomorphic, 0.5–0.8×1.0–2.5 μm, and reproduce by budding or asymmetric cell division.
Motile by peritrichous flagella.
Gram-negative.
Colonies on complex media containing peptone are circular, smooth, opaque, and orange or red.
Strictly aerobic and chemoorganotrophic.
Bacteriochlorophyll a and carotenoids are present.
Cell extract has absorption maxima at 465, 799, 814, and 861 nm.
Growth occurs at 20–37 °C with an optimum temperature of 30 °C.
Optimum pH for growth is at pH 7.0–7.5.
Little growth occurs in the absence of NaCl; optimal NaCl concentration for growth is 1%.
Growth factor requirement is satisfied by addition of 0.01% yeast extract.
Catalase and oxidase are present.
Does not hydrolyze starch, chitin, casein, gelatin, Tween 80, or DNA.
Biphenyl and dibenzofuran are degraded with concomitant production of yellow-orange pigments.
Usable carbon sources are D-glucose, sucrose, cellobiose, pyruvate, acetate, propionate, fumarate, and glutamate.
No or little growth occurs with L-arabinose, D-fructose, D-mannose, D-sorbitol, butyrate, succinate, malate, lactose, D-mannitol, lactate, methanol, ethanol, propanol, formate, and citrate.
The major cellular fatty acid is C18:1ω7cis.
Monosaccharide type of glycosphingolipid is present.
2-OH fatty acid components are C14:0, C15:0, C16:0, and C16:1.
Ubiquinone-10 is the major respiratory quinone.
The G+C content of genomic DNA ranges from 63.8 to 64.0 mol% (HPLC).
The habitats are brackish and marine environments.
The type strain is IAM 12620 (=ATCC 25659).
